conclusion: In the Stirling cycle diagram, transitions A→B and C→D are isothermal, meaning temperature remains constant.
To determine changes in molecule collisions from C to D, consider pressure, volume, and temperature in an ideal gas, and nature of collisions.
Pressure in a gas is related to the number of collisions per unit area per unit time.
For an ideal gas, pressure is related to temperature and volume via the ideal gas law: PV = nRT.
During the isothermal process from C to D, temperature remains constant.
As the gas transitions from C to D, the volume decreases.
Since temperature is constant, as volume decreases, pressure must increase to keep PV constant.
An increase in pressure means an increase in the number of collisions per unit area per unit time.
From state C to D, as volume decreases, pressure increases due to the isothermal nature of the process.
The number of molecules colliding with the unit area of the wall per unit time increases from state C to state D.
